title: What is the law re: hidden assets later revealed after the divorce?
question: I asked for an appraisal for the huge gun collection my ex acquired during our 16 yr marriage . He and his attorney told us that the collection was sold and that he only had a few old cheap pieces left . When I went for the attorney supervised walk through , his attorney let him stay ( in direct opposition of the court order ) when we got to the garage to look at gun safes , my ex went crazy . His attorney rushed me and my counsel out . Following a TOR I filed this summer ( 2 yrs later ) I exercised my civil right and got a list of his weapons registered w the DOJ / ATF . this is very different than the list stated on his attorneys inventory and quite valuable . Those were just the hand guns , his huge collection were hand made sniper riffles and scopes $ $ $ $ do I have a right to those ? And what % value ?
question_tags: Divorce,Dividing debts in a divorce,Community property in divorce,Divorce and bankruptcy,Bankruptcy,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Fees,Court orders
answers:
You may have stumbled onto the most persuasive evidence I've ever seen to demonstrate a failure to disclose. Those lawfully obtained government records, which I assume include the date of acquisition of the firearms that were registered (there may be more that were not registered), will be excellent impeachment. You should review his Preliminary and Final Declarations of Disclosure. The Schedule of Assets and Debts (FL-142) is his sworn statement of all assets. If he said "3 handguns" valued at $50, then I like your chances at a Rossi (Marriage of Rossi (2001) 90 Cal.App.4th 108) 100% award of the undisclosed assets.

I suspect you will see on his FL-142 some vague "Guns....minimal value" or similar attempt to fail to disclose while pretending to disclose. You should get an attorney, conduct discovery, take his deposition using the FL-142 he signed and the DOJ registrations. Let him talk and talk about how he disclosed. You may need to file a Request for Order to allocation undisclosed community property in order to get the discovery. Of course, you should also seek an award of your attorney fees and costs, including the DOJ records search.

Given the fact that he and his attorney appear to have gone through extraordinary measures to hide these assets, you might be able to get 100% of the value of these assets. There is case law to support this. Look up Marriage of Rossi.

You might want to file a Request For Orders seeking a full accounting of all weapons purchased during the marriage, sold during and after the marriage, and still in his possession. Ask for receipts and bills of sale, appraisals, etc.

Yes, you are entitled to 50% of the community property. Your lawyer can conduct formal discovery, including Special Interrogatories, Demands to Produce, a Deposition, and a Demand for Physical Inspection. If your husband failed to disclose the weapons in his Declaration of Disclosure's Schedule of Assets and Debts, your lawyer can file a Feldman Motion against him for sanctions and attorney's fees.
